Message.Issue: Remove IDisposable from the list of interfaces implemented by 'LogPanelViewModel' and override the base class Dispose implementation instead.
Modify 'LogPanelViewModel.IDisposable.Dispose()' so that it calls Dispose(true), then calls GC.SuppressFinalize on the current object instance ('this' or 'Me' in Visual Basic), and then returns.
Rename 'LogPanelViewModel.IDisposable.Dispose()' to 'Dispose' and ensure that it is declared as public and sealed.

'SynapsisViewModel.SynapsisViewModel(SynapsisModel, IPlateScheduler, IRobotScheduler, AbortPauseResumeStateMachine, IError, SMTPReporter)' contains a call chain that results in a call to a virtual method defined by the class. Review the following call stack for unintended consequences:
SynapsisViewModel..ctor(SynapsisModel, IPlateScheduler, IRobotScheduler, AbortPauseResumeStateMachine, IError, SMTPReporter) SynapsisViewModel.set_MenuVisibility(Visibility):Void ViewModelBase.RaisePropertyChanged(String):Void
In method 'SynapsisViewModel.CustomerProtocolComplete(object, EventArgs)', call System.IDisposable.Dispose on object 'player' before all references to it are out of scope.

Rule.Name: Dispose objects before losing scope
Rule.Description: If a disposable object is not explicitly disposed before all references to it are out of scope, the object will be disposed at some indeterminate time when the garbage collector runs the finalizer of the object. Because an exceptional event might occur that will prevent the finalizer of the object from running, the object should be explicitly disposed instead.
Rule.Resolution: In method {0}, call System.IDisposable.Dispose on object {1} before all references to it are out of scope.

Rule.Name: Do not call overridable methods in constructors
Rule.Description: Virtual methods defined on the class should not be called from constructors. If a derived class has overridden the method, the derived class version will be called (before the derived class constructor is called).
Rule.Resolution: {0} contains a call chain that results in a call to a virtual method defined by the class. Review the following call stack for unintended consequences: {1}

Rule.Name: Implement IDisposable correctly
Rule.Description: All IDisposable types should implement the Dispose pattern correctly.
Rule.Resolution: Modify {0} so that it calls Dispose(true), then calls GC.SuppressFinalize on the current object instance ('this' or 'Me' in Visual Basic), and then returns.
Remove IDisposable from the list of interfaces implemented by {0} and override the base class Dispose implementation instead.
Rename {0} to 'Dispose' and ensure that it is declared as public and sealed.
